turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Phosphorus halide.
turn.1: What are the different series of phosphorus halides?
turn.2: Phosphorus halide There are three series of binary phosphorus halides, containing phosphorus in the oxidation states +5, +3 and +2.
turn.4: All compounds have been described, in varying degrees of detail, although serious doubts have been cast on the existence of PI.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.7: What do you find to be the most interesting fact?
turn.8: In the gas phase the phosphorus pentahalides have trigonal bipyramidal molecular geometry as explained by VSEPR theory.
turn.9: Is there any other interesting aspects?
turn.10: Phosphorus pentafluoride is a relatively inert gas, notable as a mild Lewis acid and a fluoride ion acceptor.
turn.11: Why is it a fluoride ion acceptor?
turn.12: It is a fluxional molecule in which the axial (ax) and equatorial (eq) fluorine atoms interchange positions by the Berry pseudorotation mechanism.
